Package camzup.core

Class Mesh2

java.lang.Object
camzup.core.EntityData
camzup.core.Mesh
camzup.core.Mesh2
All Implemented Interfaces:
IEntityData, IMesh, ISvgWritable, IUtils, Iterable<Face2>
public class Mesh2 extends Mesh implements Iterable<Face2>, ISvgWritable
Organizes data needed to draw a two dimensional shape using vertices and faces. Given that a mesh is primarily a collection of references, it is initialized with null arrays (coordinates, texture coordinates and indices). These are not final, and so can be reassigned.

  • Field Details

    • coords

      public Vec2[] coords
      An array of coordinates.

    • texCoords

      public Vec2[] texCoords
      The texture (UV) coordinates that describe how an image is mapped onto the mesh. Typically in the range [0.0, 1.0] .

    • DEFAULT_ARC_UV_PROFILE

      public static final UvProfile.Arc DEFAULT_ARC_UV_PROFILE
      The default texture coordinate (UV) profile to use when making a cube.

    • DEFAULT_POLY_TYPE

      public static final PolyType DEFAULT_POLY_TYPE
      Type of polygon to draw when it is not supplied to the polygon function.

      The default constructor.

    • Mesh2

      public Mesh2(int[][][] faces, Vec2[] coords, Vec2[] texCoords)
      Creates a mesh from arrays of faces, coordinates and texture coordinates. The mesh's arrays are set by reference, not by value.
      Parameters:
      faces - the faces array
      coords - the coordinates array
      texCoords - the texture coordinates array

  • Method Details

    • calcUvs

      public Mesh2 calcUvs()
      Calculates texture coordinates (UVs) for this mesh. Finds the object-space dimensions of each coordinate, then uses the frame as a reference for new UVs, such that the shape acts as a mask for the texture (or, the texture fills the shape without repeating).
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • accumMinMax(Mesh2, Vec2, Vec2)
      • Vec2.resize(Vec2[], int)
      • Vec2.sub(Vec2, Vec2, Vec2)

    • clean

      public Mesh2 clean()
      Removes elements from the coordinate, texture coordinate and normal arrays of the mesh which are not visited by the face indices.
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • collapseEdge

      public Mesh2 collapseEdge(int faceIndex, int edgeIndex)
      Collapses an edge to a point. Unlike deleteVerts(int, int, int), inserts a midpoint between edge origin and destination.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      edgeIndex - the edge index
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • collapseEdge

      public Mesh2 collapseEdge(int faceIndex, int edgeIndex, float fac)
      Collapses an edge to a point. Unlike deleteVerts(int, int, int), inserts a newly created vertex between edge origin and destination according to a factor in [0.0, 1.0]; a factor of 0.5 will collapse an edge to its midpoint; of 0.0, to its origin; of 1.0, to its destination.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      edgeIndex - the edge index
      fac - the offset factor
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • Utils.mod(int, int)
      • Utils.clamp01(float)
      • Vec2.append(Vec2[], Vec2)
      • Mesh.splice(int[][], int, int, int[][])

    • flipU

      public Mesh2 flipU()
      Negates the x component of all texture coordinates (u) in the mesh. Does so by subtracting the value from 1.0.
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • flipV

      public Mesh2 flipV()
      Negates the y component of all texture coordinates (v) in the mesh. Does so by subtracting the value from 1.0.
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • flipX

      public Mesh2 flipX()
      Negates the x component of all coordinates in the mesh, then reverses the mesh's faces. Use this instead of scale(Vec2) with the argument new Vec2(-1.0f, 1.0f).
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • Mesh.reverseFaces()

    • flipY

      public Mesh2 flipY()
      Negates the y component of all coordinates in the mesh, then reverses the mesh's faces. Use this instead of scale(Vec2) with the argument new Vec2(1.0f, -1.0f).
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • Mesh.reverseFaces()

      the edges array

    • getEdgesDirected

      public Edge2[] getEdgesDirected()
      Gets an array of edges from the mesh. Edges are treated as directed, so (origin, destination) and (destination, edge) are considered to be different.
      Returns:
      the edges array

    • getEdgesUndirected

      public Edge2[] getEdgesUndirected()
      Gets an array of edges from the mesh. Edges are treated as undirected, so (origin, destination) and (destination, edge) are considered to be the same.
      Returns:
      the edges array

    • insetFace

      public Mesh2 insetFace(int faceIndex)
      Insets a face by calculating its center then easing from the face's vertices toward the center by 0.5.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      Returns:
      the new face indices

    • insetFace

      public Mesh2 insetFace(int faceIndex, float fac)
      Insets a face by calculating its center then easing from the face's vertices toward the center by the factor. The factor is expected to be in the range [0.0, 1.0] . When it is less than 0.0, the face remains unchanged; when it is greater than 1.0, the face is subdivided by center.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      fac - the inset amount
      Returns:
      the new face indices

    • insetFaces

      public Mesh2 insetFaces()
      Insets all faces in the mesh once.
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • insetFaces

      public Mesh2 insetFaces(int itr)
      Insets all faces in the mesh for a given number of iterations by a factor of 0.5 .
      Parameters:
      itr - the iterations
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • insetFaces

      public Mesh2 insetFaces(int itr, float fac)
      Insets all faces in the mesh for a given number of iterations by a factor in the range [0.0, 1.0] .
      Parameters:
      itr - the iterations
      fac - the inset factor
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • reframe

      public Mesh2 reframe(Transform2 tr)
      Centers the mesh about the origin, (0.0, 0.0), and rescales it to the range [-0.5, 0.5] . Emits a transform which records the mesh's center point and original dimension. The transform's rotation is reset.
      Parameters:
      tr - the output transform
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • accumMinMax(Mesh2, Vec2, Vec2)
      • Transform2.rotateTo(float)
      • Utils.div(float, float)
      • Utils.max(float, float)
      • Vec2.mul(Vec2, float, Vec2)
      • Vec2.sub(Vec2, Vec2, Vec2)

    • subdivEdge

      public Mesh2 subdivEdge(int faceIndex, int edgeIndex)
      Subdivides an edge by a cut at its midpoint. Does not distinguish between interior edges, which have a complement elsewhere, and border edges; for that reason this works best with NGONs.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      edgeIndex - the edge index
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • subdivEdge

      public Mesh2 subdivEdge(int faceIndex, int edgeIndex, int cuts)
      Subdivides an edge by the number of cuts given. For example, one cut will divide an edge in half; two cuts, into thirds.

      Does not distinguish between interior edges, which have a complement elsewhere, and border edges; for that reason this works best with NGONs.
      Parameters:
      faceIndex - the face index
      edgeIndex - the edge index
      cuts - number of cuts
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • subdivFace

      public Mesh2 subdivFace(int faceIdx)
      Subdivides a convex face. Defaults to center-based subdivision.
      Parameters:
      faceIdx - the face index
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • subdivFaceCenter

      public Mesh2 subdivFaceCenter(int faceIdx)
      Subdivides a convex face by calculating its center, cutting each of its edges once to create a midpoint, then connecting the midpoints to the center. This generates a quadrilateral for the number of edges in the face.
      Parameters:
      faceIdx - the face index
      Returns:
      this mesh

    • subdivFaceFan

      public Mesh2 subdivFaceFan(int faceIdx)
      Subdivides a convex face by calculating its center, then connecting its vertices to the center. This generates a triangle for the number of edges in the face.
      Parameters:
      faceIdx - the face index
      Returns:
      the new face indices

    • subdivFaceInscribe

      public Mesh2 subdivFaceInscribe(int faceIdx)
      Subdivides a convex face by cutting each of its edges once to create a midpoint, then connecting each midpoint. This generates peripheral triangles and a new central face with the same number of edges as the original. This is best suited to meshes made of triangles.
      Parameters:
      faceIdx - the face index
      Returns:
      the new face indices

    • subdivFaces

      public Mesh2 subdivFaces()
      Subdivides all faces in the mesh once.
      Returns:
      this mesh

      this mesh

    • toObjString

      public String toObjString()
      Renders the mesh as a string following the Wavefront OBJ file format.
      Returns:
      the string

    • toObjString

      public String toObjString(int vIdx, int vtIdx, int vnIdx, boolean flipvs)
      Renders the mesh as a string following the Wavefront OBJ file format. The index offsets specify where the mesh's data begin; OBJ file indices begin at 1, not 0. The mesh is considered a group, 'g', not an object, 'o'.
      Parameters:
      vIdx - coordinate index offset
      vtIdx - texture coordinate index offset
      vnIdx - normal index offset
      flipvs - whether to subtract y from 1.0
      Returns:
      the string

    • toOrigin

      public Mesh2 toOrigin(Transform2 tr)
      Centers the mesh about the origin, (0.0, 0.0), by calculating its dimensions then subtracting the center point. Emits a transform which records the mesh's center point. The transform's rotation and scale are reset.
      Parameters:
      tr - the output transform
      Returns:
      this mesh
      See Also:
      • accumMinMax(Mesh2, Vec2, Vec2)
      • translate(Vec2)
      • Transform2.rotateTo(float)
      • Transform2.scaleTo(float)
      • Vec2.negate(Vec2, Vec2)

      Useful when consolidating multiple mesh entities into one mesh entity.

      this mesh

    • arc

      public static Mesh2 arc(float startAngle, float stopAngle, float oculus, int sectors, Mesh2 target)
      Creates an arc from a start and stop angle.
      Parameters:
      startAngle - the start angle
      stopAngle - the stop angle
      oculus - the size of the opening
      sectors - number of sectors in a circle
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the arc

    • arc

      public static Mesh2 arc(float startAngle, float stopAngle, float oculus, int sectors, PolyType poly, UvProfile.Arc profile, Mesh2 target)
      Creates an arc from a start and stop angle. The granularity of the approximation is dictated by the number of sectors in a complete circle. The thickness of the arc is described by the oculus. Useful where sectors may be faster than the Bezier curves of Curve2.arc(float, float, float, camzup.core.ArcMode, Curve2) or where there is an issue rendering strokes.
      Parameters:
      startAngle - the start angle
      stopAngle - the stop angle
      oculus - the size of the opening
      sectors - number of sectors in a circle
      poly - the polygon type
      profile - the uv profile
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the arc

    • detachFaces

      public static Mesh2[] detachFaces(Mesh2 source)
      Creates an array of meshes, each with one face from the source mesh. Leaves the source mesh unaltered. New meshes are created through visitation of each face in the source, so they may contain redundant data to be removed with clean().
      Parameters:
      source - the source mesh
      Returns:
      the meshes array

    • fromCurve2

      public static Mesh2 fromCurve2(Curve2 source, int resolution, float colinearTol, Mesh2 target)
      Converts a curve to a mesh. If the fore handle and rear handle of a curve segment are colinear according to a tolerance, then only two vertices are added; otherwise evaluates the Bezier curve, producing one line segment per the requested resolution.
      Parameters:
      source - the source curve
      resolution - the line segment count
      colinearTol - the colinear tolerance
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the mesh

    • fromCurve2

      public static Mesh2 fromCurve2(Curve2[] arr, int resolution, float colinearTol, Mesh2 target)
      Converts an array of curves to a mesh. If the fore handle and rear handle of a curve segment are colinear according to a tolerance, then only two vertices are added; otherwise evaluates the Bezier curve, producing one line segment per the requested resolution.
      Parameters:
      arr - the source curves
      resolution - the line segment count
      colinearTol - the colinear tolerance
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the mesh

    • fromPoints

      public static Mesh2 fromPoints(Vec2[] points, Mesh2 target)
      Creates a mesh from a series of points. Does not check for vertex winding, so the order of each point should match its intended vertex order. There should be at least 3 points in the array.
      Parameters:
      points - the points
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the mesh

    • gridHex

      public static Mesh2 gridHex(int rings, float cellRadius, float margin, Mesh2 target)
      Generates a grid of hexagons arranged in rings around a central cell. The number of cells follows the formula n = 1 + (rings - 1) * 3 * rings, meaning 1 ring : 1 cell, 2 rings: 7 cells, 3 rings: 19 cells, 4 rings: 37 cells and so on. See Red Blob Games' Implementation of Hex Grids .
      Parameters:
      rings - the number of rings
      cellRadius - the cell radius
      margin - the margin between cells
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the hexagon grid

    • gridHex

      public static Mesh2 gridHex(int rings, float cellRadius, Mesh2 target)
      Generates a grid of hexagons arranged in rings around a central cell. The number of cells follows the formula n = 1 + (rings - 1) * 3 * rings.
      Parameters:
      rings - the number of rings
      cellRadius - the cell radius
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the hexagon grid

    • gridHex

      public static Mesh2 gridHex(int rings, Mesh2 target)
      Generates a grid of hexagons arranged in rings around a central cell. The number of cells follows the formula n = 1 + (rings - 1) * 3 * rings.
      Parameters:
      rings - the number of rings
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the hexagon grid

    • proximity

      public static Map<Float,Vert2> proximity(Mesh2 m, Vec2 p, float nearBound, float farBound)
      Returns a collection of mesh vertices organized by their proximity to a point. The proximity is expressed as a factor where the nearest vertex is on the nearBound; the farthest is on the farBound. Any function which mutates a vertex's properties by such a factor can be applied to the collection.

      The Euclidean distance from a point is unsigned, so two points may have approximately the same distance from the point yet be in different quadrants of the Cartesian coordinate system, i.e. not organized by proximity to each other.
      Parameters:
      m - the mesh
      p - the point
      nearBound - the factor near bound
      farBound - the factor far bound
      Returns:
      the collection
      See Also:
      • getVertices()
      • Vec2.distSq(Vec2, Vec2)

      public static Mesh2 square(Mesh2 target)
      Creates a square.
      Parameters:
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the square

    • square

      Creates a square. Useful when representing an image plane with a mesh entity.
      Parameters:
      target - the output mesh
      poly - the polygon type
      Returns:
      the square

    • tracePerimeter

      public static Mesh2 tracePerimeter(Mesh2 source, int count, float offset, Mesh2 target)
      Traces the perimeter of each face of the source mesh. Returns a target mesh where all faces have the number of vertices specified by the count; each face will be inscribed within the source face, where the target vertices lie on an edge of the source. The perimeter is treated as a percent in the range [0.0, 1.0] , so, for example, a square face's corners will occur at 0.0, 0.25, 0.5 and 0.75 .
      Parameters:
      source - the source mesh
      count - the number of vertices
      offset - the factor offset
      target - the output mesh
      Returns:
      the traced mesh
      See Also:
      • Utils.mod1(float)
      • Vec2.resize(Vec2[], int)

    • uniformData

      public static Mesh2 uniformData(Mesh2 source, Mesh2 target)
      Restructures the mesh so that each face index refers to unique data, indifferent to redundancies. As a consequence, coordinate and texture coordinate arrays are of equal length and face indices are easier to read and understand. Useful for making a mesh similar to those in Unity or p5. Similar to 'ripping' vertices or 'tearing' edges in Blender.
      Parameters:
      source - the source mesh
      target - the target mesh
      Returns:
      the mesh
      See Also:
      • Vec2.resize(Vec2[], int)
